H0.text: who proposed the first accurate model of dna. Rosalind Franklin

H1.text: who proposed the first accurate model of dna. Linus Pauling

H2.text: who proposed the first accurate model of dna. Erwin Chargaff

H3.text: who proposed the first accurate model of dna. Crick

A4.text: Her two manuscripts on form A DNA reached Acta Crystallographica in Copenhagen on 6 March 1953, one day before Crick and Watson had completed their model.

A5.text: The Watson and Crick model was not the first 'bases in' model, as Sven Furberg had proposed that idea earlier.

A6.text: Watson and Crick completed their model, which is now accepted as the first correct model of the double helix of DNA.

A7.text: Linus Pauling and Robert Corey proposed a model for nucleic acids containing three intertwined chains, with the phosphates near the axis, and the bases on the outside.

A8.text: Seven-page, handwritten letter that Crick sent to his 12-year-old son Michael in 1953 describing the structure of DNA.

A9.text: Linus Pauling and Watson and Crick had erroneous models with the chains inside and the bases pointing outwards.

A10.text: Franklin's high-quality X-ray diffraction patterns of DNA were unpublished results, which Watson and Crick used without her knowledge or consent in their construction of the double helix model of DNA.

A12.text: Early in 1953 Watson and Crick proposed a correct structure for the DNA double helix.
